conclusion: Understanding the concept of electromagnetic induction and how the induced electromotive force (EMF) is calculated in different scenarios.
A straight metal rod is moving perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field at a speed v.
The rod is perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic induction intensity.
The induced EMF (ε) in the rod is given by the formula: ε = B ⋅ v ⋅ L.
The rod is bent into two equal-length segments that are perpendicular to each other.
The rod moves at a speed v in the direction of the angle bisector of the included angle of the two segments.
Each segment of the rod is now L/2 in length.
For each segment, the velocity component perpendicular to the segment is v ⋅ cos(45°) = v/√2.
The induced EMF in each segment is: ε_segment = B ⋅ (v/√2) ⋅ (L/2) = B ⋅ v ⋅ L/(2√2).
Since the two segments are perpendicular, their EMFs add up: ε' = 2 ⋅ B ⋅ v ⋅ L/(2√2) = B ⋅ v ⋅ L/√2.
The original EMF for the straight rod is ε = B ⋅ v ⋅ L.
The EMF for the bent rod is ε' = B ⋅ v ⋅ L/√2.
The ratio is: ε'/ε = (B ⋅ v ⋅ L/√2)/(B ⋅ v ⋅ L) = 1/√2.
